explanation:
To determine whether OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl calls itself (directly or indirectly) we must follow all call paths out of the function and see if any path returns to it. The listed symbols are required for that call-graph analysis:

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: This is the direct callee from OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl; its implementation (and any callees it uses) must be inspected to see if it can (directly or indirectly) call back into OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl.

- OS_FileSysStatVolume: This is the external caller/wrapper of the Impl function. It must be checked because cycles can involve wrapper functions (e.g., Impl -> ... -> FileSysStatVolume -> Impl). Any calls from this wrapper that could lead back to the Impl must be examined.

- OS_printf, OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch, OS_ObjectIdRelease, UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: These are the callees of OS_FileSysStatVolume according to the static call graph. To be sure there is no indirect recursion via the wrapper, their implementations (and any further callees) need inspection to confirm they do not invoke OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl (or call chains that do).

Note: OS_ObjectIndexFromToken has no recorded callees in the static graph; if its implementation indeed makes no further calls, then there is no path returning to OS_FileSysStatVolume_Impl. However, the actual implementations of the listed symbols must be examined to confirm there are no hidden/indirect call paths (including through function pointers) that would create recursion.
